scenario:
Northrop Grumman has been awarded a $3.46 billion contract by the US Navy to develop the E-130J, a "Doomsday Plane" that will serve as a mobile command center in the event of a nuclear war. The contract is part of the TACAMO Recapitalization Program and will involve modifying up to six Lockheed Martin C-130J-30 cargo planes to include advanced communications and sensor gear. The project is expected to be completed by December 2034.

This contract is in addition to Northrop Grumman's existing role as a major contractor to the Navy, building E-2D Advanced Hawkeye AWACS planes and MQ-4C Triton drone aircraft. The company also won the Air Force's B-21 Raider contract in 2015, which could yield up to $200 billion in sales.

However, the aeronautics division, which includes the E-130J project, is Northrop Grumman's least profitable division, with an operating profit margin of around 10% in the first three quarters of 2024. The company's other three main business divisions typically earn higher profit margins.

The contract is not expected to have a significant impact on Northrop Grumman's stock price, as it is relatively small compared to the company's annual sales and is not expected to be particularly profitable. The stock is currently trading at 28.5 times trailing earnings, making it a relatively expensive investment.
